awd_titl_txt: CoPe EAGER: Using Undergraduate Engineers and Community Engagement to Build Resilient Coastal Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
In contrast to large metropolitan areas that have resources to prepare for sea level rise, there are many small underserved coastal communities that do not have the resources to design and implement engineering solutions to address the challenges caused by sea level rise. In this project, the expertise of community members will be linked with the expertise of undergraduate engineering students to create a framework to help a small community develop plans for adapting to sea level rise. The research team and students will interact with members of the community through various community engagement techniques. The resulting generalizable model has the potential to improve community involvement in the design process for building more resilient coastal communities. Additionally, the framework will support the design of plans at a significantly reduced financial cost, which will further promote sustainability in the community. This community-driven design framework will provide undergraduate engineering students experience designing real-world projects with societal benefit. This project will also demonstrate the value of linking university expertise and community engineering needs. 

This project will link the knowledge embedded in rural coastal communities with the engineering expertise of undergraduate students to design solutions that build resilience and bolster the participation of marginalized communities in adaptation planning. Through the interdisciplinary efforts of engineers and social scientists, the objectives of this work are: (1) develop a framework where the research team engages community members and engineering students to advance a community-based design process focused on generating solutions to issues caused by sea level rise; (2) document local community members' perceptions of the contributions of the framework to resiliency; and (3) assess how community interaction affects engineering student outcomes. This framework will involve citizens to identify the critical problems and determine how to best address community needs. The research team will hold small focus groups to foster detailed discussions with knowledgeable stakeholders, conduct frequent meetings with a core stakeholder group that represents the many interests in the community, and host quarterly public meetings to keep the broader community informed and gather additional feedback. The involvement of engineering students and community engagement techniques to advance engineering design will result in a low-cost approach for resource-limited coastal communities that will promote community resilience.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Coastal communities throughout the world are having to deal with rising sea levels. In contrast to large metropolitan areas that have resources to prepare for sea level rise, there are many small communities along the coast that do not have the resources to design and implement engineering solutions to address the challenges caused by sea level rise. The many ABET-accredited engineering programs throughout the United States provide a potential source of knowledge to assist the communities with fewer resources. In this project, the expertise of community members was linked with the expertise of undergraduate engineering students completing their senior capstone projects. The goal was for the students to engage a rural community to help them develop concept plans for adapting to sea level rise that include input from community members from the very beginning of the design process. The research team and students interacted with members of the community through small focus groups, a core stakeholder group, and public meetings.

The research team began meeting with members of the community to develop a plan for integrating this project into the ongoing efforts in the watershed of a local lake in early 2020. The team met with members of a core stakeholder group along with members of the community to identify the challenge areas that would be assigned to the three senior engineering capstone teams. The project team considered feedback from all community members before selecting three focus areas that met community needs and the educational objectives for the capstone projects.

The three focus areas selected were: (1) improving the four existing outflow canals; (2) directing water onto an adjacent 42,500 acre drainage association that has existing pump infrastructure and land available for water treatment; and (3) redirecting water from private property that currently drains to the lake to another body of water following treatment. Each of these areas was chosen for a specific reason. The focus area of the canals was chosen because many of the stakeholders requested this option be investigated and it had not been pursued to this point in the watershed restoration process. The option of the drainage association was pursued because of the existing pump infrastructure that had the potential to handle the large volume of water coming from the watershed that was the focus of this project. The third focus area was chosen because it could serve as a model for smaller landowners that wanted to implement their own project to reduce flooding and improve water quality in the lake.

The students began their projects in August 2020 and completed them in April 2021. The expected in-person community engagement planned for this project had to be altered due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Most of the student engagement with the community ended up being virtual and primarily with the core stakeholder group. Although the meetings were virtual, the students presented their progress and results to the community multiple times. Each student team was also a part of a focus group with members of the community to get feedback on their proposed designs. These focus groups were facilitated by one of the PIs on the project. The research team facilitated community engagement training with the student teams and provided feedback on their interactions with community members throughout the period they were working on their projects to help them better communicate with non-engineers.

In April 2021, members of the research team conducted individual interviews with the students to assess how community interactions affected student outcomes. From these interviews the research team found that the students: (1) recognized the power of community knowledge to improve the engineering solutions, (2) had a greater awareness of the broader context of their work, (3) gained a deeper understanding of the local importance of the ecosystem, (4) improved communication skills, and (5) gained experience in receiving and acting on public critique.  Through working with the students and evaluating their designs, the research team learned: (1) the students were challenged by how to conduct an economic analysis for their projects, (2) the community was more concerned with recurring costs than design details, (3) community feedback and students' lack of time influenced the areas where students devoted their time, and (4) this framework was effective for evaluating what was desired by the community.

Since the students completed their concept plans, other partners in the community have applied for and received funding to implement the project that redirected water from private property to another body of water following treatment. They have also further investigated the potential of dredging an outflow canal. These efforts were greatly advanced by the work done by the students. This model, although it was conducted during the COVID-19 pandemic, has shown great potential to improve community involvement in the design process.
